newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-CANBERRA WATCH - Costello fudges on A$8 bln cut.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-CANBERRA WATCH - Costello fudges on A$8 bln cut.

text.p: Australian Treasurer Peter Costello is fudging on the A$8 billion of promised spending cuts.
This number has been fiscal policy's Rock of Gibraltar since a supposed black hole of those dimensions was revealed on March 12.
On Friday this exchange occurred between Costello and a reporter at a Melbourne doorstop news conference.
Reporter: "Do you plan to implement A$8 billion in savings next year despite anything the Senate does this year?"

Costello: "I put down A$7.2 billion. It's a two year programme, I'm asking (for) the right of the elected government to implement that programme in the parliament and what we do after that, we'll have a look."
If nothing had changed Costello would have answered "Yes, of course."
Instead he said wait and see.
This is a startling turnaround from what everyone has been assuming since Tuesday's budget.

The budget produced almost exactly the half of A$8 billion savings that Costello had long promised, rising to A$7.2 billion in 1997/98, which we have taken as a substantial downpayment on the entire fiscal programme.
That is, we have assumed there is a Costello IOU for A$800 million in annual savings plus whatever the Senate knocks out when budget legislation goes before it.
But there are two reasons to suspect that the government might see whatever survives the Senate as good enough.
First, the announced programme is already enough to meet the target year for an underlying balance, which slipped to 1998/99 when the worse-than-expected 1995/96 deficit was announced on July 16.
Providing Senate obstruction does not cost too much that target is easily obtainable on current forecasts.
The second reason for thinking Costello might not bother with the rest of the A$8 billion is that those forecasts may be conservative.
Already Prime Minister John Howard has described as conservative the labour force forecasts, which are crucial for pay-as-you-earn tax revenue and social security spending.

Access Economics budget analyst Chris Richardson thinks the budget will be in strong underlying surplus in 1997/98, a year early, largely because he thinks Treasury has underestimated the labour market.
Costello himself hinted that he also thinks the forward estimates may be pessimistic.
Shortly after dodging a commitment on the A$8 billion Costello was asked at a fund-raising lunch how he would like to report on the economy in a year's time.
"I would like to be able to say that in the forthcoming year we'll go close to balance, although on current projections it would be a deficit, it'd be a very small deficit," he said.
